Paul Jack wrote:
>  > I created 3 use cases here:
>  >
>  > http://www.cs.odu.edu/~fmccown/heritrix/use_cases.html 
> 
> So I have filled out the red bits in case #1 and case #2, but I'm not
> sure what you're asking in case #3 -- "How could the rule be applied
> *after* getting the URL?" Can you maybe clarify your question for
> me? (A better way to handle the requirement of only handling .html
> files might be to look for the content-type of text/html as in case
> #2, but I like that case #3 tries a different approach.)

Hello Paul-

I appreciate you taking the time to edit my use cases.  I've only been 
using Heritrix a few months, so I hope what I have written so far makes 
sense.

To clarify, what I was wondering was if there was a way we could access 
a URL like http://foo.org/bar/dir, and if it returns a redirect to 
http://foo.org/bar/dir/ we would accept it using our regexp.  This is 
probably not the best approach to take though since it would be rather 
wasteful considering how infrequently we would get a redirect response. 
  I would just ignore this comment.

I agree that a better approach would usually be to just accept all 
resources with a mime type of text/html, but I wanted to show how we 
could apply a regexp to a URL *before* we grab it.  I think this would 
be useful for some types of focused crawling.

Thanks again,
Frank
